author: Im_A_MechanicalMan
body:
Hindsight can really kick your hind if you let it!

&#x200B;

If I had bought Amazon in 1999.

If I had bought Netflix a decade later.

If I had bought the gamestore at 4 dollars and sold at 480 dollars.  Then rebought at 50 dollars and sold at 250 dollars.

If I had bought AMD when it was 10 dollars.

If I had etc...

But I didnt, because it didn't make sense to me at the time.  It was a large risk in all these situations and I didn't have enough information to convince me otherwise.

A thousand other things cratered that I could have bought into that I didn't.  But it is easier to focus, after the fact, on the few successful trades that would have worked out.

body:
**$IonQ**: High risk high reward

**$Qualcomm**: Low risk medium reward.

author: esqualatch12
body:
My take on stock investing in general is it really works in levels. You do not touch the higher levels of investing until you have a firm understanding and success at the lower. 
The lowest level is ETF investing, easy to learn easy to toss money at and make returns. Also builds a strong base to work from

 The 2nd is individual stock, once you really learned to analyze investment data. You can also work on the emotional side of your investments in this area like not panicking during a selloff or becoming to elated in your gains not to sell.

The 3rd level is learning the various trading options such as limits, stop losses and margins. Really it can be bundled into the 2nd BUT these things are generally more important for traders rather Investors.

Finally we get to options, if you don't have a firm grasp and decent experience with the above then you need to stay the hell away from options. They are the ultimate trap to newbie investors who see dipshits on WSB gambling away there entire savings. HOWEVER, a reasonable experienced investor whom can make sound decisions in there investments in the previous level can  infact benefit from limited option trading (can never recommend an all in). 

I for one am sitting on some delicious AMD 87.5 leap calls that don't expire til next June. I felt they were a reasonable investment as the XLNX merger was already know.

3. alternative chip - Apple shown us ARM is viable alternative to Intel's x86. AWS, Google and Alibaba is all in on design their own chip. 


Can Intel catch up?

author: SnipahShot
body:
I think you might not know the difference between insiders and institutions. Insiders are officers and directors of the companies. Institutions are hedge funds.

Retail investors probably don't have the money to keep it going up, but hedges do.

It isn't that hard to check what he is saying about insiders selling. Insider selling means that they believe the current price is too high for their company, otherwise they would have kept the stocks.

Look at a few companies and their insider activity -

Tesla: 10 shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 9.2mil shares sold in that time.

AMD: 0 shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 3mil shares sold in that time.

Nvidia: 206k shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 1.5mil shares sold in that time.

Moderna: 0 shares were bought in the last 12 months. 13.6mil shares were sold in that time.

&#x200B;

Now let's look at companies whose value didn't spike.

Analog Devices: 840k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 310k shares were sold in that time.

Intel: 430k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 250k were sold in that time.

Norwegian Cruise: 480k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 370k shares were sold in the last 3 months.

&#x200B;

It does not indicate whether the market will crash, but it indicates what insiders think of the valuation of the company they are part of.

author: BeardlessPete
body:
Secured puts can be used to enter a position. Let's say you want to go long AMD and it's at 150 you can sell a secured put for a strike of 149. If you get assigned then 1 you are entering in on the trade at a discount and 2 you're getting a small premium. 

It's actually kind of cool because you get paid for entering a long trade. Ideally, if you're a long term investor and you're going to hold for many years, then entering trades with secured puts is a good idea because you'll always enter your positions below highs and you'll take a premium for doing so that you can use to buy more of the shares. You'll only get enough premium to get maybe 1 extra share if you sell a weekly CC, but if it's a stock like AMD that 1 share can do a lot of work.

Another thing is a lot of people will do the wheel by entering with CSP, but I'm not really a fan of that. You have to enter and exit every once in a while, and I feel like just holding for the long term is the best play.

author: Khatib22
body:
Just wanted to share my experience too. I fully agree - after seeing all the gains on this sub from FDs (weeklies) it's kind of hard not to feel like "F it, I wanna make some money too" and YOLO your money in - VERY BAD DECISION. It would be hard for me to pay attention at work and school since my mind would just be focused on trying to chase gains and praying that my portfolio wouldn't be red. Then, I eventually lost like $4k in total. It was initially hard to stomach the loss but I had to just accept it as a learning lesson. 

I also just wanted to say I fully agree with you on the LEAPS in safe companies. 80% of my portfolio is stocks and 20% LEAPS. LEAPS are great ways to control more of a stock with less money and I make sure to only buy LEAPS on great fundamental companies (NVDA and AMD) but am planning to buy some SPY GOOGL and MSFT LEAPS that you mentioned as well.

I just want to say that I actually sleep better now and my quality of life is MUCH better. I realized I just couldn't handle the stress of 90%+ swings in my portfolio without being glued to it or worrying "IS IT TIME TO SELL?" LEAPS and shares remove all of that because they don't really have an "expiration." Shares are unlimited and LEAPS are like 2-3 years out so there's no rush to feel like: THE STOCK HAS TO RALLY 20% in a day, all you have to do is choose companies you have high conviction in and let them naturally make their way up.

author: Ja_Nee_Misschien
body:
Intel is mainly behind because they failed to order a lot of EUV machines early unlike TSMC and Samsung. This can be fixed by spending a bigger share of the profits on capex and buying a lot of these advanced EUV machines themselves and that is exactly what they are going to do and what pissed of some investors. Intel announced they will be the first to receive the next iteration of even more advanced EUV machines soon.

By being a foundry Intel can use all their IP for their customers. This will give them an advantage over TSMC and Samson for a sizable chunk of the market. Simply because they can throw in this IP so customers can design product only intel can make. Their packaging techniques are not the same as those of TSMC and at least a sizable share of the market will benefit from these. I'm not going to claim they will steamroll TSMC but they will be able to take market share. It's a new market. It will be the same as AMD doubling their data center business by taking a few percentages of market share from Intel. In the foundry business TSMC will be like Intel and Intel will be like AMD.

As a foundry you can make whatever the client designs. Intel clearly stated they will go for a mix and match strategy where clients can combine external IP like ARM with Intel IP like packaging or networking. X86 will always have a place but Intel clearly accepted that it's not only x86 anymore and they are adapting.

author: Vi0lentByt3
body:
You have to really watch and research the tickers you want to play with options, they can be simple but only if you put in a lot of work to identify the signals for when to make simple trades. It took me 2 years of watching and trying to play amd to finally know when to buy calls and puts and profit consistently. Always stick to what you know and research the shit out of anything new you want to get into.
ALSO the beauty of options is that you can always profit no matter whats happening to a stock. Up, down, flat, sharp price increase, slow burn down, any moves a stock is making there is always an effective strategy to provide th best chance of profit. NEVER lock yourself into a single option strategy otherwise you will severely diminish the companies and the timeframes you can trade. Start small and work up from there dont go chasing dragons after seeing those massive wsb gains

author: bugtimtim
body:
The costs to produce the chips are way too high. 

Just building a foundry to make semiconductors can run you up to 4 billion dollars, before you even buy the raw materials, or staff the foundry. 

In order to make money, or even break even producing chips, you need to constantly push out product. And companies like ford or gm don't have the demand to warrant making their own product. 

Even companies like AMD, and Nvidia don't produce their own chips, and their sole business exists to sell them. 

This is also the reason we haven't seen the semiconductors recover like we saw lumber recover earlier this year. 

Lumber has a relatively short and cheap startup cost, so opening up more mills to produce higher quantities of lumber is profitable, quick, and relatively easy to do, in many cases, the mills already existed, but they were just running at low capacity. 

To start up a new semiconductor foundry, you'd have to invest billions of dollars. Then you'd quickly catch up to demand, and you would be left with a billion+ dollar foundry that's not producing anything because demand went down.

First off:

Check the cost of certificates for Disney stock that sell online. Not the value of the shares, but the paper certificates themselves. These are collectors items, and look into this first before you get rid of the certificates.

Secondly, do you have a broker? Like, a real broker that isn't Robinhood? Contact Charles Schwab, vanguard, fidelity, or one of the many other real brokerages and see (if you have an account) how much these certs would be in real value today if redeemed, with dividends.

author: JonathanL73
body:
1.) High rate of accounts getting hacked, some even with 2FV enabled.

2.) For the longest time they didn't even have a customer support phone number, they're difficult to get ahold of if a problem arises.

3.) Unstable and unreliable app, RH became completely unusable, multiple times during the Covid March 2020 crash. When other brokers stayed operational

4.) Payment for order flow. RH makes money buy selling your buy orders to high frequency trade hedge funds, who are then able to "frontrun" the stock, meaning they can buy the stock a milisecond before you do, thus raising the price your market orders get filled. So you're actually paying more for stocks on RH than if you used another broker.

5.) Conflict of interest, RH primary customer, Citadel was caught illegally naked shorting meme stock. During the meme stock frenzy, RH users weren't allowed to buy shares of certain companies, whereas with other brokers you could.

6.) RH has history of being fined by the SEC, and countless lawsuits regarding not having the best user's interest in mind.

7.) Glitchy Options display. RH falsely displayed losses for a young options trader who was actually in the green. He ended up committing suicide because of it.

8.) If you care about margin %, Interactive Brokers and M1 Finance both have cheaper margin %

9.) Not good for buying Crypto. You don't have access to your wallet keys, and you're not allowed to transfer your crypto to anew wallet, so you're forced to liquidate it if you want to move it elsewhere, which creates a taxable event. Also questions have raised if RH really holds the crypto that you "own" on their app.

Also it's not 2019 anymore, it's 2021. Countless apps have clean simple UI. SoFi & Fidelity Beta both have clean UI

author: NoleScole
body:
Idk what wells fargo has been doing but settled cash applies to all brokerages unless you have a margin account. You can’t set up market trade at any brokerages. You can set up a limit order. I think you might be saying you can’t buy or sell at market, after hours. With fidelity you have to sign up for after hours trading. Then you have to go to their website to trade after hours or pre market hours. It isn’t available in the app.

I use fidelity for long term I’ve been with them for years. They’re not my favorite to navigate though. I prefer others for trading and watchlist.

author: MythrowawayAcc5678
body:
I'm still with RH but not very much money is it in. for example, RH has a really nice and simple layout combined with the DRIP option, something webull doesn't have. on top of that, RH's graphs are super easy to read, and show all the info without it being cluttered. Fidelity doesn't live stream stocks meaning unlike with RH, you need to refresh every 5 seconds to see the price movements. 

I use fidelity for my Roth, RH for my second smaller portfolio, and webull for day trading and other stuff. Coinbase is for crypto. typically I find it better to separate portfolios and some layouts are better than others. you wouldn't use robinhood for extreme technical analysis and you wouldn't use webull for long term buy and hold.

author: sorengard123
body: Simple, quality of investor base. A CFO's dream is blue-chip long only funds like Fidelity and Wellington which buy and hold forever. Management doesn't want hedge funds grilling them every quarter over why the margin isn't 20bp higher or activists threatening to fire them. They want investors who trust them to run the business well over the long-term. There's a reason why Charter Communications is bullet proof. It has the highest institutional ownership on the Street and spends zero time courting investors or investment banks.

author: McKoijion
body:
There's a legit investing lesson here. I used to say that Robinhood had a well designed app UI, but a terrible back end infrastructure. Meanwhile, Vanguard, Fidelity, and Schwab have great back end infrastructure, but terrible, outdated UIs. I used to think what those companies did was the hard part, and Robinhood just put some paint on a pig. I joked it was a race to see who could fix themselves up faster. But it's been almost a year, and those old school websites are as bad as ever.

Vanguard's bad UI is somewhat on purpose, and Schwab bought TDA and Thinkorswim. But Fidelity is an embarrassment. Active Trader Pro is the single oldest and worst performing piece of software I've had the misfortune of interacting with in the past decade. Their mobile app is terrible as well, though I commend them for trying to introduce a nicer looking, but still barely functional Robinhood knockoff beta.

Basically, good design is priceless. But since an investor's job is to put a price on things, I'll just say it's very valuable. Haters always said that Steve Jobs was just the pretty boy frontman, but there are a lot of computer companies and only one is the largest corporation on the planet by simply coasting on Jobs's designs. It's hard to write good code or build a brokerage, but it's almost impossible to create good design.

Basically, leaps on $MLKN

author: tebedam
body:
Just move your money to Interactive Brokers, that's what I did. It takes about 10 business days, the process is automated. Whatever margin you already have will also transfer.

I tried margin on Fidelity for a month, had ~$350k on margin and kept trying to negotiate a better deal with multiple phone calls. All I got in the end was 5.5%. After that I moved the account and now my blended rate is ~1.2%. 

I set up a PRO account on IBKR, you pay a few fees and commissions this way, but overall get massive value due to low margin rates.

author: Conscious-Soil9055
body:
Webull (Their app and desktop program are by far the best I've used. they lack a couple of features but they release weekly updates)

Fidelity (They are by far the most conservative and least risky, they will frustrate you at times but its really to stop you from doing dumb things.) Fidelity is also nice because i manage 5 different retirement accounts there.

E-Trade (I've heard great things, never used or seen, but people that do rave)

I just opened an account with IBKR only for the low margin rate for my long term taxable account. It is very clunky. Fidelity's simple web version blows IBKR out of the water.

author: Praughfet
body:
Depending on the trade and reserve capital,  if  iam out of settled funds and complete a trade for say $500 profit or more,  ill wire money right back in and take the 30 fee as cost of business to have those funds ready again in 15 minutes.

GFV was tricky.. i did get pinged at first , which made no sense to me

 i had an hour long phone call with fidelity about the GFV and the guy could flat out not answer me..   For OTC you have to trade with settled funds, a GFV is a trade made without settled funds, so how can that be....after an hour back and forth with the lackey i finally got transferred to a senior broker and was told to look at my cash available to withdraw to gauge if a GFV is possible.  no further problems.
